step1.sentence: A good manager takes responsibility for their team's outcomes, not just the successes.

step2.story: He had made the call that led to the failed product launch. He could have distributed the blame across the team. Instead, he stood in front of the company and said it was his decision and his to own. The room was quiet. Two people sent him private messages afterward saying it was the most respected thing they had seen a leader do in years.

step3.story: The philosophy of the program was simple: you take responsibility for what you can control, and you practice releasing what you cannot. For participants recovering from various forms of crisis, this distinction was not always obvious. Many spent months unable to separate the two. The facilitators did not rush the process. They had found that the willingness to take responsibility for one's own part — even a small part, even one easily dismissed as circumstantial — was often the first movement toward recovery. Not because it assigned blame, but because it assigned agency.
